channel.title: Rash Docs â€“ Documentation
channel.description: Recent content in Documentation on Rash Docs

item.title: Algorithms
item.description:
Binary search

bs.rash
// Simple binary search implementation with a wrapper so that the user doesn't need to specify the left and right

fn search_wrapper(array, l, r, target) {
    if l > r; {
	    print(f"Target ${target} not found")
	    return {-1};
    }

    middle = r - l; 
    middle = middle / 2;
    middle = middle + l;

    if target == array[middle]; {
	    return {middle};	
    } else if target < array[middle]; {
	    return {search_wrapper(array, l, middle - 1, target)}
    } else {
	    return {search_wrapper(array, middle + 1, r, target)};
    }
}

fn search(array, target) {
    r = len(array) - 1;
    return {search_wrapper(array, 0, r, target)};
}

Also accessible through the std:

algo.rash
import {algorithms};
arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

index = search(arr, 2)
print(f"Target 2 found at index: ${index}")

item.title: Arrays
item.description:
Arrays are the most complex type in Rash:

int.rash
array = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5];
print(arr[0]); // 0-indexed
print(arr[-1]); // Negative indexing (Goes from the end)

Methods

int.rash
array = pop(array)
array = push(array, 7)
array = swap(array, 0, 42)

item.title: Booleans
item.description:
Bools are also very simple:

int.rash
rash_is_cool = true;
bash_is_cool = false;

item.title: Conditions
item.description:
Rash supports if, else if and else

conditions.rash
x = 1;

if x == 1; {
  print("I love rash")
} else if x != 1; {
  print("I still love rash")
} else {
  print("Rash is the best")
}

item.title: Functions
item.description:
Bash supports functions, define your own like so:

functions.rash
fn add(x, y) {
  print(f"Adding ${x} and ${y}");
  return {x + y};
}

// Call them like so
z = add(5, 6)

item.title: Getting Started
item.description:
Install 

git clone https://github.com/ThatBlokeJosh/rash.git
cd rash
cargo build
./target/debug/rash script.rash

item.title: Integers
item.description:
Integers are very simple:

int.rash
x = 5;
y = 4;
z = x + y;
print(f"The sum of ${x} and ${y} is ${z}");

item.title: Loops
item.description:
Similarly to Go, Rash has two loop types

Standard iterator style

loops.rash
arr = [0, 1, 5, 6]
for i = 0; i < len(arr); ++i; {
  print(arr[i]);
}

While loop style

loops.rash
for true; {
  print("Bash stinks")
}

item.title: Operations
item.description:
Supported binary operations are:

variables.rash
  x = 5; // Assignment
  x + 4; // Adittion
  x - 1; // Subtraction
  x * 4; x / 2; // Multiplication and division
  x == 4 && x <= 2; // And, or, equals, lesser, greater etc.

item.title: Strings
item.description:
Strings are an important part of Rash, there are three types of strings:

Standard strings

strings.rash
name = "Josh";
print(name);

Formated strings

fstrings.rash
name = "Josh";
print(f"My name is ${name}");

Command strings

cstrings.rash
url = "https://pokey.remington.boo";
c"curl ${url}"; // Prints to stdout

files = c"ls"; // Doesn't print and saves it in a variable
print(files);

item.title: Variables
item.description:
Rash has a dynamic type system not to dissimilar to pythons, variables are declared like so:

variables.rash
  name = 5; // Optional semi-colon
  print(name);

  text = "Hello World"

  rash_is_cool = true;

  arrr = [0, 4, 2, 1]
